items.title: Myntra secures $81m fund infusion from Flipkart
items.summary:
- Myntra received ₹709 crore (US$81 million) from Flipkart in November 2024, following a previous investment of ₹29.5 crore (US$339 million) in March 2023.
- Myntra's revenue grew 15% to ₹5,121 crore (US$584 million) with a net profit of ₹30.9 crore (US$3.5 million).
- This funding is part of Flipkart's transition from Singapore to India ahead of a potential public listing.

items.title: AI startup TrueFoundry secures $19m series A
items.summary:
- TrueFoundry raised $19 million in series A funding led by Intel Capital, with participation from Peak XV Partners, Jump Capital, and others.
- Founded in 2021 by former Meta engineers, the startup provides an AI deployment platform for enterprises to optimize machine learning operations.
- TrueFoundry now supports generative AI deployments on multiple cloud platforms including AWS, Google Cloud, Azure, and on-premise solutions.
- The funding will facilitate US expansion, hiring for sales and product marketing, and partnerships with cloud providers.

items.title: Should Temasek cast net in startup waters after eFishery fiasco?
items.summary:
- eFishery allegedly inflated its revenue by nearly US$600 million from January to September 2024.
- The startup has notable investors including SoftBank and Temasek Holdings.
- The investigation into eFishery's financial impropriety is ongoing and has raised questions about due diligence by investors.
- State-linked investors like Temasek have limited early-stage investment exposure to 6% of their total portfolio, minimizing their potential losses.

items.title: Stripe acquires stablecoin API Bridge for $1.1b deal
items.author: Zach Abrams, Sean Yu
items.summary:
- Stripe has acquired Bridge, a stablecoin API platform, for $1.1 billion.
- This acquisition is Stripe's largest to date and marks an expansion into the cryptocurrency market.
- Bridge, co-founded by Zach Abrams and Sean Yu in 2022, provides APIs for businesses to accept stablecoins and has raised $58 million from investors.

items.title: Google to compensate Israeli users in Play Store settlement
items.summary:
- Google has begun compensating Israeli consumers as part of a class action settlement regarding its Play Store subscription policies.
- Total compensation amounts to 46.5 million shekels (approximately US$13.1 million).
- The lawsuit, initiated in 2017 by Mordechai Malachi, alleged that Google misled users about its auto-renewing subscription policies.
- Users will receive 55% refunds of their subscription fees, and those who canceled early will get a one-time 25% compensation.
- The Central District Court in Lod approved the settlement in September 2024.
- Malachi will receive 1.9 million shekels, while attorneys are awarded 8.06 million shekels in legal fees.
- Individual refunds are expected to range from several dozen to a few hundred shekels per user.
- Google will enhance transparency around auto-renewals and allow immediate cancellations with proportional refunds.

items.title: Dubai-based AI visa platform secures $700k funding
items.author: Vladimir Indjikian, Alena Iakina
items.summary:
- Dubai-based Visarun.ai has raised US$700,000 in pre-seed funding from undisclosed angel investors.
- The funding will help develop the platform and expand into new markets like the UAE, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, India, and China.
- Founded in 2024, Visarun.ai aims to streamline visa processing, reducing manual work by up to 70% with its Smart Visa Route system.
- The platform manages 10,000 visa applications per month and plans to introduce features like AI-based virtual interviews and advanced document verification.

items.title: Intel to cut 58 more jobs
items.summary:
- Intel is cutting 58 more positions at its Folsom, California campus by March 31.
- This follows over 1,000 job losses at the site since January 2023 as part of a larger initiative that cut 23,000 employees globally since late 2022.
- The layoffs are part of Intel’s strategy to save US$10 billion by 2025.
- The company also announced plans to sell and partially lease back its Folsom property in November 2024, indicating continued downsizing.

items.title: OpenAI launches data residency to meet EU regulations
items.summary:
- OpenAI launched data residency options for European customers on Feb. 6 to comply with GDPR requirements.
- This feature allows data storage and processing within Europe, specifically for OpenAI’s API.
- API requests processed in Europe do not retain data, following increased regulatory scrutiny.

items.title: Indian auto platform Droom cuts losses by 35% in FY24
items.summary:
- Droom reduced its consolidated net losses by 35% in FY24 to 40.4 crore rupee (US$55.43 million) from 62.1 crore rupee (US$85.2 million).
- Expenses decreased by 64% to 100.9 crore rupee (US$138.43 million).
- Operating revenue dropped by 66% to 85.4 crore rupee (US$117.16 million).
- EBITDA losses reduced to 37.2 crore rupee (US$51.04 million) from 57.3 crore rupee (US$78.61 million).
- Founded in 2014, Droom focuses on mid-premium and luxury cars, offering services like car financing and rentals.
- Total revenue, including other income, reached 90 crore rupee (US$123.47 million) for FY24.
- The company plans to file a draft red herring prospectus with SEBI by June 2025 to raise 1,000 crore rupee (US$1.37 billion) through an IPO, targeting a valuation between US$1.2 billion and US$1.5 billion.

items.title: No-code platform Zapi launches content builder for all
items.author: Jonathan Low
items.summary:
- A new no-code content site builder, Zapi, has been launched.
- Available at [heyzapi.com](http://heyzapi.com).
- Co-founded by CEO Jonathan Low, who recently announced his appointment.
- Further details about Zapi’s services and market strategy are still emerging.

items.title: DeepSeek limits access to AI services, ends discounts
items.summary:
- DeepSeek is restricting API services due to server capacity limits.
- Customers can't add to their API credits, but existing credits remain unaffected.
- Restrictions follow a surge in demand for their AI chatbot launched in January.
- New user signups are limited to those with a mainland China phone number.
- As of Feb. 8, DeepSeek will terminate discounts for AI model access.
- Pricing will be 2 yuan (US$0.27) per million input tokens and 8 yuan (US$1.10) for output tokens; reasoning model priced at 4 yuan (US$0.55) per million input tokens and 16 yuan (US$2.20) for output tokens.

items.title: YouTube runs TikTok ads to lure creators amid US ban
items.summary:
- YouTube has initiated an ad campaign on TikTok to attract creators due to potential US restrictions on TikTok.
- The ads promote the advantages of YouTube, including gifts and community interaction.
- A law coming into effect in January 2025 may lead to TikTok's removal from US app stores, but enforcement is postponed until April.
- YouTube Shorts is expected to gain from a potential TikTok ban, while rivals like Instagram and X are enhancing features to draw creators.
- Google has not commented on its advertising approach, and TikTok has remained silent on their response.
- US-China tensions are rising, with China probing Google for antitrust violations and considering actions against Apple due to trade tariffs.

items.title: Swiggy shares hits 52-week low as Q3 losses widen
items.summary:
- Swiggy's shares have reached a 52-week low following a wider loss reported in Q3.
- The company's financial performance continues to show significant challenges in the competitive food delivery market.
- This development raises concerns about Swiggy's long-term sustainability and investor confidence.

items.title: EU presses Shein on online safety, consumer risks
items.summary:
- The European Commission has issued a request for information (RFI) to Shein as part of compliance under the EU’s Digital Services Act (DSA).
- Shein must respond by February 27, providing details on risks related to illegal content, consumer protection, and data transparency.
- Shein was designated as a Very Large Online Platform (VLOP) in April 2024, leading to stricter EU supervision.

items.title: Indian gaming startup PlaySuper raises $500k seed funding
items.summary:
- Indian gaming startup PlaySuper has successfully raised $500,000 in seed funding.
- The funding round aims to enhance PlaySuper's gaming platform and expand its user base.
- The startup is focusing on engaging and casual gaming experiences tailored for Indian audiences.

items.title: Weekly funding: CashFree rakes in $53m to take top spot
items.author: Queena Wadyanti, Charmaine de Lazo
items.summary:
- CashFree has raised $53 million in funding this week.
- The article lists top funding deals across Asia.
- Full details are available through a subscription service from Tech in Asia.

items.title: US lawmakers propose bill to ban DeepSeek on gov’t devices
items.author: Darin LaHood, Josh Gottheimer
items.summary:
- Bipartisan bill proposed to ban Chinese AI software DeepSeek on government devices due to national security concerns.
- Representatives Darin LaHood (R-Ill.) and Josh Gottheimer (D-N.J.) leading the legislation.
- Concerns raised about espionage and data collection capabilities linked to the Chinese Communist Party.
- Previous developments include DeepSeek's rise in global downloads and allegations of producing harmful content.

items.title: SoftBank nears $6.5b deal to acquire chipmaker Ampere
items.summary:
- SoftBank Group Corp. is in advanced discussions to acquire Ampere Computing LLC for approximately $6.5 billion, including debt.
- An announcement regarding the acquisition could happen in the coming weeks, though delays are possible.
- Ampere specializes in processors for data centers using Arm technology and is backed by Oracle Corp. and Carlyle Group Inc.

items.title: DeepSeek surpasses Doubao as China’s fastest-growing AI app
items.summary:
[DeepSeek's chatbot app becomes the most popular AI application in China, surpassing Doubao]
[Recorded 22.2 million daily active users (DAUs) in January, against Doubao's 17 million]
[DeepSeek launched for Android on Jan. 8 and iOS on Jan. 10, growing rapidly to 21 million DAUs within three weeks]

items.title: Europe faces data center shortage amid AI growth
items.summary:
- European data centers set to increase capacity by 22% in 2023 but still unable to meet rising demand.
- Risks posed to Europe’s AI development due to challenges like grid congestion and site shortages.
- Secondary markets in cities like Milan, Warsaw, and Berlin are growing, yet European investment in AI infrastructure significantly trails the US, which is investing US$500 billion.

items.title: Telio’s shutdown signals deeper B2B ecommerce woes
items.author: Sy Phong Bui
items.summary:
• Telio, prominent B2B ecommerce firm in Vietnam, shut down in late 2024 after failing to secure funding or acquisition.
• Operations suspended in November 2024; approximately 400 employees laid off.
• Previously reduced monthly losses from US$1.4 million to US$280,000 by August 2024, but unable to achieve projected funding of US$10-15 million.
• Founded in 2019, aimed to connect small retailers with brands; faced challenges such as high operational costs and thin margins.
• Closure followed significant cost-cutting efforts initiated in mid-2022.

items.title: Taiwan’s economy grows on AI, tech demand amid uncertainty
items.summary:
- Taiwan's economy shows growth driven by increased demand for AI and technology.
- The economic outlook remains uncertain due to external factors.
- Significant contributions from tech industries to GDP highlight the importance of innovation in maintaining economic stability.

items.title: 50 most active investors in Southeast Asian, Indian greentech firms
items.summary:
[Highlights the 50 most active investors in the greentech sectors of Southeast Asia and India.]
[Identifies key players and their investment activities in sustainable technology.]
[Discusses trends and the growing importance of greentech investments in the region.]

items.title: Carsome partners with MUFG unit
items.summary:
- Carsome Group partners with Japan Consumer Credit Service (JACCS), part of Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group.
- The collaboration aims to enhance auto financing solutions in Malaysia for underserved segments.
- JACCS will acquire a 49% stake in Carsome Capital, while Carsome retains 51%.
- Focus on improving risk assessments and credit governance for financial sustainability.

items.title: Zomato changes corporate name to Eternal
items.summary:
- Zomato has officially changed its corporate name to Eternal.
- This rebranding move signifies Zomato's new business direction and strategy.
- The change is part of a broader trend among tech companies to refresh their corporate identities.

items.title: Bukalapak’s next subject: edtech
items.summary:
- Bukalapak is expanding its focus to include education technology (edtech).
- The move is part of the company's strategy to diversify its services and offerings in the digital space.
- This shift aims to address the growing demand for online education solutions in the region.

items.title: Meet the 50 top-funded startups and tech companies in Japan
items.summary:
[Japanese startups are evaluated based on the amount of money raised from investors.]
[The list includes startups that have raised funds in the past two years only.]
[Special thanks to East Ventures for assisting in compiling the list.]

items.title: Ex-Google engineer faces espionage charges over AI theft
items.summary:
- Linwei Ding, a former Google engineer, faces 14 charges including seven counts of economic espionage and seven for trade secret theft.
- Accused of stealing proprietary technology related to Google’s chip design crucial for AI models like Gemini and GPUs.
- Allegedly started a business in China in 2023 using the stolen technology and applied for a Shanghai talent program offering financial incentives.
- If convicted, Ding could face up to 15 years in prison for each economic espionage charge and up to 10 years for each trade secret theft charge.

items.title: Taiwan’s APT forecasts 30% growth driven by AI demand
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- AblePrint Technology Co (APT) anticipates a 30% revenue growth this year due to increased demand for AI products.
- APT continues to receive steady orders from major clients, including TSMC, Intel, and Samsung, despite potential AI sector slowdowns.
- The company generates 80% of its revenue from advanced chip packaging, focusing on CoWoS technology.
- In 2024, APT's revenue rose by 51% to 1.8 billion New Taiwan Dollars (US$55.1 million).
- APT's net profit increased by 24.5% during the first three quarters of 2024.
- The company plans to debut on the Taipei Exchange on Feb. 26, with a share price set at 1,250 New Taiwan Dollars (US$38).

items.title: Google drops diversity targets amid DEI program overhaul
items.summary:
- Google discontinues specific hiring goals for underrepresented groups in a shift in its DEI efforts.
- CEO Sundar Pichai's 2020 target to increase leadership representation by 30% by 2025 is no longer pursued.
- A DEI commitment statement was removed from the annual SEC filing amidst ongoing program reviews.
- Google will maintain support for internal employee networks like “Trans at Google” and the “Black Googler Network.”

items.title: Amazon to unveil AI-enhanced Alexa with new features
items.summary:
- Amazon will unveil an AI-enhanced version of Alexa on **Feb. 26** at an event in **New York**.
- The upgraded Alexa can handle multiple prompts and perform tasks autonomously, unlike the current version.
- Initially free for a limited number of users, with subscription fees expected to range from **US$5 to US$10** per month.
- The new Alexa will work with existing devices and offer personalized recommendations, using technology from **Anthropic**, an AI software startup.

items.title: ByteDance unveils AI model OmniHuman-1 for lifelike videos
items.summary:
[ByteDance has introduced its new AI model called OmniHuman-1.]
[The model aims to create lifelike videos that can replicate human expressions.] 
[This development represents a significant advancement in AI technology for video generation and content creation.]

items.title: OpenAI co-founder John Schulman leaves Anthropic
items.summary:
- John Schulman resigns from his role at Anthropic, where he joined in 2024.
- Anthropic confirmed his departure on February 5.
- Schulman focused on AI alignment and technical work at Anthropic after leaving OpenAI in August 2024.
- Anthropic, a competitor to OpenAI, provides foundation models through partnerships with cloud providers like Amazon Web Services.
- Recent developments include:
  - [Citations feature to improve AI accuracy](http://www.techinasia.com/news/anthropic-launches-citations-feature-to-improve-ai-accuracy) launched on January 24, 2025.
  - [Google invests $1 billion more in Anthropic](http://www.techinasia.com/news/google-invests-1b-more-in-anthropic-total-reaches-2b) on January 22, 2025, totaling over $2 billion.
  - [Open-source tool for easy AI access](https://www.techinasia.com/news/anthropic-launches-opensource-tool-easy-ai-access) launched on November 26, 2024.
  - [Partnership with Snowflake to enhance data through AI](https://www.techinasia.com/news/anthropic-snowflake-partner-enhance-data-ai) announced on November 22, 2024.
  - [Projected $850M revenue by 2024](https://www.techinasia.com/news/anthropic-eyes-850m-revenue-2024-ai-demand-grows) reported on December 27, 2023, up from an estimate of $500M.
  - [Talks to raise $750M at $18.4B valuation](https://www.techinasia.com/news/anthropic-talks-raise-750m-valuation-184b) ongoing as of December 21, 2023.

items.title: Snap appoints ex-Meta India head as CBO
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Snap Inc has appointed Ajit Mohan as its chief business officer (CBO).
- The appointment was announced by CEO Evan Spiegel during the Q4 2024 earnings call.
- Mohan was previously Snap's Asia Pacific president and will oversee the global advertising business.
- He has held notable positions at Meta India and Disney+ Hotstar.

items.title: Qualcomm Q1 revenue hits $11.72b
items.summary:
- Qualcomm reported fiscal Q1 revenue of $11.72 billion, an 18% increase from $9.92 billion last year.
- Net income rose 15% to $3.18 billion, or $2.83 per share, compared to $2.77 billion or $2.46 per share a year earlier.
- For the next quarter, Qualcomm projects revenue between $10.2 billion and $11 billion.

items.title: Google launches Gemini 2.0 with Pro, Flash-Lite models
items.summary:
- Google DeepMind has made its Gemini 2.0 Flash model widely available through the Gemini API in Google AI Studio and Vertex A.
- An experimental Gemini 2.0 Pro model targets advanced coding and complex prompts, offering a context window of 2 million tokens.
- Gemini 2.0 Flash-Lite is a budget-friendly option in public preview, balancing performance and affordability.
- All models support multimodal input and text output, with anticipated future updates for image generation and text-to-speech capabilities.
- Further pricing information is available on the Google Developers blog.

items.title: TikTok’s US woes jolt SEA merchants
items.summary:
- TikTok's operational issues in the US are affecting Southeast Asian (SEA) merchants.
- The uncertainty around TikTok's future could impact revenue avenues for businesses relying on the platform.
- SEA merchants are exploring alternative platforms and adjusting strategies in response to TikTok's challenges.

items.title: 50 rising startups in Japan
items.summary:
- The article lists startups in Japan that are raising funding and considered to be on the path to becoming the next big thing.
- It includes companies up to the series E stage.
- Details about the funding rounds of these startups are provided.

items.title: Flipkart’s chief product, technology officer resigns
items.summary:
- Flipkart's Chief Product and Technology Officer has resigned.
- The resignation reflects a significant development within the company's leadership.
- No further details provided regarding reasons for the departure or future implications.

items.title: Flipkart’s CPTO resigns for personal reasons
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Jeyandran Venugopal has resigned as Chief Product and Technology Officer (CPTO) of Flipkart, citing personal reasons.
- Flipkart CEO Kalyan Krishnamurthy confirmed the announcement in an internal memo.
- Venugopal worked at Flipkart for six years, overseeing product management, engineering, design, and data science.
- He previously worked at Myntra and currently chairs Nasscom’s Deeptech Council.

items.title: China’s online merchants consider price hikes amid tariffs
items.summary:
- Chinese merchants are considering price hikes due to new tariffs and rising shipping costs.
- USPS has temporarily halted parcel shipments from China and Hong Kong.
- A seller reports a 35% increase in shipping fees for textiles and 25% for other goods starting Feb. 4.
- The recent tariff increase by President Trump raised Chinese goods' tariffs by 10% and eliminated the de minimis exemption.
- The de minimis exemption allowed packages under US$800 to enter duty-free, which significantly supported China's e-commerce growth.
- Nearly half of de minimis shipments originated from China, making this policy change a substantial setback for Chinese sellers.

items.title: Arm trims forecast, shares drop 6% despite Q3 beat
items.summary:
- Arm Holdings has revised its revenue guidance to US$3.94 billion to US$4.04 billion, lower than previously forecasted.
- In Q3, Arm reported US$983 million in revenue, a 19% year-on-year increase, exceeding estimates.
- Shares fell 6% in after-hours trading despite beating Wall Street expectations.
- The company anticipates fourth-quarter revenue between US$1.18 billion and US$1.28 billion, slightly above analyst projections.
- Focus on expanding royalties from the new Armv9 chip technology and data center applications.

items.title: JD.com seeks to acquire Germany’s retailer Ceconomy
items.summary:
- JD.com is looking to acquire Ceconomy, a German retailer.
- The acquisition aims to expand JD.com's presence in the European market.
- Ceconomy operates MediaMarkt and Saturn chains, focusing on consumer electronics.

items.title: Indian women’s wellness startup secures $4m pre-series C
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Nua, a women’s wellness and hygiene brand, raised 35 crore rupees (US$4 million) in a pre-series C funding round led by Mirabilis Investment Trust.
- Notable investors include Samir Singh from Colgate Palmolive and Shuchi Kothari from DSP Family Office.
- The funds will support retail expansion and new product launches in marketplaces and offline retail.
- Nua has raised a total of US$21.5 million from various investors, including Lightbox VC and Deepika Padukone.

items.title: Snapchat gains from TikTok uncertainty, sees strong growth
items.summary:
- Snapchat CEO Evan Spiegel mentioned that TikTok’s uncertain future has positively impacted Snapchat's growth.
- Engagement temporarily rose when TikTok was offline, benefiting Snap’s overall business environment.
- The feature Spotlight, which competes with TikTok, saw a 40% increase in creators posting content year-over-year.
- Snapchat's public content grew significantly, reaching a billion public posts per month in Q4.
- The platform reported 453 million daily active users, an increase of 39 million.
- Revenue for Q4 was US$1.55 billion, marking a significant year-over-year increase.

items.title: Swiggy Q3 losses rise, quick commerce drives growth
items.summary:
- Swiggy recorded a consolidated net loss of ₹799 crore (US$91.28 million) in Q3 FY25, a 39.1% increase from ₹574.4 crore (US$65.62 million) last year.
- Loss rose sequentially by 27.7% from ₹625.5 crore (US$71.46 million) in the previous quarter.
- Operating revenue grew by 31% year-on-year to ₹3,993.1 crore (US$456.18 million).
- Instamart, Swiggy’s quick commerce arm, contributed a loss of ₹527.68 crore (US$60.18 million), a 70% increase from last year, while its revenue surged by 114% to ₹576.50 crore (US$65.86 million).
- Added 96 active dark stores, totaling 2.45 million square feet.
- Swiggy plans to continue expanding its business-to-consumer segments, especially in quick commerce.
- Recent developments include the resignation of the company secretary and fluctuations in share value with significant focuses on new app launches.

items.title: Uber Q4 2024 profit misses expectations, shares fall
items.summary:
- Uber reported a profit of 23 cents per share, missing expectations of 50 cents.
- Shares fell by 6% in pre-market trading, influenced by rising costs.
- Total revenue increased by 20% year-over-year to $11.96 billion, surpassing expectations.
- Costs rose 20.5% to $11.19 billion, leading to an operating income of $770 million.
- Ride-hailing revenue grew by 25% and delivery revenue by 21%, both exceeding estimates.
- Gross bookings for the quarter were $44.2 billion, supported by strong demand for commutes and holiday deliveries.
- For Q1, Uber estimates gross bookings between $42 billion and $43.5 billion, slightly lower due to currency fluctuations.
- CEO Dara Khosrowshahi aims to boost demand in 2025 by offering competitive rates and controlling insurance costs.

items.title: S Korea nuclear plant operator bans ChatGPT, DeepSeek
items.summary:
- Korea Hydro & Nuclear Power Co. (KHNP) has banned AI services like ChatGPT and DeepSeek, effective February 1.
- The ban aims to protect sensitive data and personal information.
- KHNP becomes the first state-owned company in South Korea to block the DeepSeek AI platform.

items.title: AI model s1 rivals OpenAI’s o1 with $6 training cost
items.summary:
- A new AI model named **s1** was introduced on **Feb. 2**.
- It achieves near state-of-the-art performance at a low training cost of only **$6**.
- The model was trained on a distilled dataset from **Qwen2.5** using **16 Nvidia H100 GPUs**.
- Training time for a single run was **26 minutes**.
- Innovations like s1 allow for experimentation with limited resources, contrasting with larger organizations like **OpenAI**.
- Concerns have been raised regarding **distealing**, the use of distilled datasets from other AI models, prompting industry debates on ethical issues.

items.title: China’s AgiBot, Kazakhstan to set up first robotics center
items.summary:
- AgiBot is establishing its first manufacturing facility in Central Asia in partnership with Kazakhstan.
- The project includes production plants, a robotic training data center, and an R&D center.
- This marks the first localization of Chinese robotics production in Kazakhstan, aligning with the country’s strategy to diversify its economy through AI and advanced manufacturing.
